Toasted Level Manager/source/driver.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /***************************************************************************
00002         Author: Sheridan Beebe
00003         Game:   Toasted
00004         File:   driver.c
00005         Date:   January 16th, 2007
00006         Description:
00007                         This file is used only as a sample driver. Its purpose is to
00008                         provide an example of the way to interface with the level
00009                         loading/management system. The actual level system should
00010                         be contained within LevelManager.c and LevelManager.h.
00011 ***************************************************************************/
00012 
00013 /*!
00014         \mainpage Toasted Level Manager
00015 
00016         \section intro Introduction
00017 
00018         This is the documentation for the Toasted level management system and such.
00019         Check out the different sections in order to find out info on the methods.
00020         Everything should be commented correctly, if you find any discrepancies, let
00021         me know. Have fun.
00022 
00023         \section links Useful Links
00024 
00025         The most important page in this documentation is the documentation on the level
00026         management header. Here is a <A HREF="_level_manager_8h.html">link</A>.
00027 
00028         \section readme A Short Readme
00029 
00030         To use the level management system, you need to include the file LevelManager.h.
00031         Doing so will give you access to all of its functions, types, and defines. Before
00032         the level management system can be used, the function loadLevelManager() should
00033         be called. Usualy this will be called by the game when it first starts, so you
00034         shouldn't have to worry about it. The function unloadLevelManager() should also
00035         be called just before the program exits.
00036 
00037         To set the position of something in the level manager, you first need to create
00038         a new LEVEL_POSITION. You can do this using createLevelPosition(). Chances are
00039         how ever, that if you are working with a subsystem, the level loading system
00040         will pass you a pointer to a LEVEL_POSITION when it informs you that you are to
00041         create something new. You should use this LEVEL_POSITION instead of creating a new one.
00042         Once you have a LEVEL_POSITION, you can place it somewhere on the map using the function
00043         setLevelPosition(). On the opposite side, you can get the LEVEL_POSITION at a
00044         specific position using the function getLevelPosition(). If you need to change an
00045         old position into a white space(ie, an empty space) you should set the level position
00046         to the already available LEVEL_POSITION created for all white space. This position is
00047         named whiteSpacePosition. It is a global so it should be accessible after including the
00048         LevelManager.h header.
00049         
00050         If you are working with another part of the game, and for what ever reason, you need
00051         to load a LEVEL you should use the function loadLevel(). This function will load the
00052         LEVEL with the specified file name(relative to the application exe) and set it as 
00053         the current LEVEL in use. Before loading a new LEVEL, the old LEVEL should be unloaded
00054         using the function, unloadLevel().
00055 
00056         For any other information, see the documentation for the LevelManager.h header.
00057 */
00058 
00059 /* include some things to help us print and such to the console */
00060 #include <stdio.h>
00061 #include "LevelManager.h"
00062 
00063 /* main method */
00064 int main(void)
00065 {
00066         /* variables used for testing purposes */
00067         int xSpace = 22, ySpace = 12, xWall = 0, yWall = 10, xSome = 27, ySome = 8;
00068         LEVEL_POSITION *somePosition, *newPosition;
00069         LEVEL *currentLevel;
00070 
00071         /* print a welcome message... */
00072         printf("Welcome to the level management driver example for Toasted.\n");
00073 
00074         /* show off the level management features */
00075 
00076         /* init the level manager, MUST be done */
00077         loadLevelManager();
00078 
00079         /* Load a new level - sets it as the current level */
00080         loadLevel("testlevel.tlf");
00081 
00082         /* Get a pointer to the struct containing the info for a given level location */
00083         somePosition = getLevelPosition(WEAPON_LAYER, xSome, ySome);
00084 
00085         /* print out the character at some position */
00086         printf("The position (%i,%i) contains a '%c' character.\n", xSome, ySome, somePosition->character);
00087 
00088         /* create a new level position struct and put in some information */
00089         newPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_ENEMY, 'E');
00090 
00091         /* Set the pointer to the struct containing the info for a given level location */
00092         setLevelPosition(0, 27, 5, newPosition);
00093 
00094         /* Quick method returns whether a location contains a space struct (ie. empty) */
00095         if(isLevelPositionSpace(WALL_LAYER, xSpace, ySpace))
00096         {
00097                 printf("There is a space at (%i,%i).\n", xSpace, ySpace);
00098         }
00099         else
00100         {
00101                 printf("There is not a space at (%i,%i).\n", xSpace, ySpace);
00102         }
00103 
00104         /* Quick method returns whether a location contains a wall struct (ie. is there a wall here) */
00105         if(isLevelPositionWall(WALL_LAYER, xWall,yWall))
00106         {
00107                 printf("There is a wall at (%i,%i).\n", xWall, yWall);
00108         }
00109         else
00110         {
00111                 printf("There is not a wall at (%i,%i).\n", xWall, yWall);
00112         }
00113 
00114         /* Get the current level */
00115         currentLevel = getCurrentLevel();
00116         printf("The current level's file name is: ");
00117         puts(currentLevel->fileName);
00118         printf("The level's width is: %i, height is: %i.\n", currentLevel->width, currentLevel->height);
00119 
00120         /* unload the level manager, must be done after the level manager is finish being used,
00121            before the program exits. */
00122         unloadLevelManager();
00123 
00124         /* print out a short status message, for fun */
00125         printf("Level has been unloaded.\n");
00126 
00127         /* exit the program */
00128         return 0;
00129 }
